cosmology.name: The Great Wheel
cosmology.description: The default D&D cosmology includes more than two dozen planes. The most common understanding visualizes them as a group of concentric wheels, with the material realms at the center. The Inner Planes form a wheel around the Material Plane, enveloped in the Ethereal Plane. The Outer Planes form another wheel around that one, arranged according to alignment, with the Outlands linking them all.

alternateConfigurations.name: World Tree
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes situated among the roots and branches of a great cosmic tree (literally or figuratively)

alternateConfigurations.name: Vertical Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Material realms suspended between two other realities: the astral realms (the Astral Plane and the Outer Planes) above and the elemental realms (the Inner Planes) below

alternateConfigurations.name: Simplified Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: A cosmology with fewer planes: a Material Plane; the Transitive Planes; a single undifferentiated Elemental Plane; an Overheaven where good deities and Celestials dwell; and an Underworld where evil deities and Fiends reside

alternateConfigurations.name: Orbital Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes arranged in a complex system of orbits, with planes exerting greater influence on the Material Plane the closer they draw to it

planeCategories.name: Material Realms
planeCategories.description: Most D&D worlds are located on the Material Plane, which has two planar echoes: the Feywild and the Shadowfell.

planeCategories.name: Transitive Planes
planeCategories.description: The Ethereal Plane and the Astral Plane are boundless realms that provide passage between other planes of existence.

planeCategories.name: Inner Planes
planeCategories.description: The four Elemental Planes (Air, Earth, Fire, and Water), plus the Para-elemental Planes between them, are the Inner Planes.

planeCategories.name: Outer Planes
planeCategories.description: Seventeen Outer Planes correspond to the nine alignments and shades of philosophical difference between them.

planeCategories.name: Positive and Negative Planes
planeCategories.description: These two planes enfold the rest of the cosmology, providing the raw forces of life and death that underlie all existence in the multiverse.

planes.name: Mount Celestia
alternateNames: The Seven Heavens of Mount Celestia
planes.philosophicalEssence: The model of justice and order, of celestial grace and endless mercy. Angels and champions of good guard against incursions of evil. Inhabitants strive constantly to be as righteous as possible. Only the purest souls can reach the highest and most sublime peak of the mountain.
planes.emotionalInfluence: The pervasive goodness of Mount Celestia bestows blessings on creatures on the plane. Even the most jaded of travelers are filled with awe at its highest peak.

physicalProperties.shape: A sacred mountain rising from a shining Silver Sea to utterly incomprehensible heights, with seven plateaus marking its seven heavenly layers.

temperature.description: Varies by layer; ranges from the Silver Sea at the base through golden light, snowy slopes, luminescent fog, sweeping plains, to the ineffable heights of Chronias.

physicalProperties.dominantElement: None; a plane of spirituality and thought rather than elemental substance

layers.name: Lunia
layers.description: In the Silver Heaven, the holy water of the Silver Sea laps at the base of the celestial mountain under a starry sky.

notableLocations.name: Silver Sea
notableLocations.description: A shining sea of holy water that laps at the base of the celestial mountain, serving as the arrival point for visitors to the plane.

layers.environmentalDescription: A starry sky over a sea of holy water at the mountain's base. This is the arrival layer where fiends of all sorts launch doomed assaults on its shores.

layers.name: Mercuria
layers.description: The Golden Heaven's tame slopes and lush valleys are bathed in golden light that evokes the hope of a new dawn.
layers.environmentalDescription: Tame slopes and lush valleys bathed in golden light evoking the hope of a new dawn.

layers.name: Venya
layers.description: In the Pearly Heaven, terraced fields and tended woodlands dot the snowy slopes.
layers.environmentalDescription: Terraced fields and tended woodlands on snowy slopes.

layers.name: Solania
layers.description: In the Crystal Heaven, holy shrines glitter under a silvery sky amid luminescent fog.

notableLocations.name: Mines of Solania
notableLocations.description: Mines coveted by the yugoloths of the Lower Planes for their wealth.

layers.environmentalDescription: Holy shrines glittering under a silvery sky amid luminescent fog.

layers.name: Mertion
layers.description: On the sweeping plains of the Platinum Heaven, holy soldiers muster in grand citadels for battles across the planes.

notableLocations.name: Empyrea
notableLocations.description: A city on the edge of a clear lake, renowned for the healing power of its fountains and springs. Pilgrims from across the planes seek out the healers, hospitals, and restorative magic found here.

layers.environmentalDescription: Sweeping plains with grand citadels where holy soldiers muster for battles across the planes.

layers.name: Jovar
layers.description: The Glittering Heaven, strewn with beautiful rubies and garnets, is home to the seven-tiered Heavenly City.

notableLocations.name: Heavenly City
notableLocations.description: A seven-tiered city located in the Glittering Heaven, amid scattered rubies and garnets.

layers.environmentalDescription: Strewn with beautiful rubies and garnets. The yugoloths of the Lower Planes covet the scattered gems of Jovar.

layers.name: Chronias
layers.description: The Illuminated Heaven is an ineffable mystery. Only the purest souls can reach this highest and most sublime peak of the mountain.
layers.environmentalDescription: An ineffable mystery at the peak of the mountain. Only the purest souls can reach it.

timeFlow.description: Distance is a virtually meaningless concept on the Outer Planes. A perceptible region of a plane might seem quite small on one visit, and on another trip can stretch on to what seems like infinity.

environmentalEffects.name: Pervasive Goodness
environmentalEffects.description: The pervasive goodness of Mount Celestia bestows blessings on creatures on the plane.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: Blessings are bestowed on creatures on the plane. Specific effects are described under Environmental Effects in chapter 3 of the DMG.
environmentalEffects.emotionalEffect: Visitors feel the pervasive goodness of the plane, and even the most jaded travelers are filled with awe at its highest peak.

requirement.description: A portal to Mount Celestia might be located on a mountain peak, as portals often have thematic similarities to their destination plane.
requirement.situationCondition: Located on a mountain peak with thematic similarity to the celestial mountain

requirement.description: A gate-town portal in the Outlands settlement of Excelsior, which shares many characteristics of Mount Celestia.

portals.name: Astral Color Pool to Mount Celestia

civilizations.name: Empyrea
civilizations.description: A city on the edge of a clear lake in Mertion, renowned for the healing power of its fountains and springs. Pilgrims from across the planes seek out the healers, hospitals, and restorative magic found here.

savingThrow.triggerDescription: After finishing a Long Rest on Mount Celestia, a Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. Mount Celestia is an Upper Plane, which is alien to the nature of Fiends.

onFailure.description: Whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save.
onFailure.cumulativeDescription: The effect is cumulative with each failed save. Each failed save adds another 1d4 subtracted from D20 Tests.

onSuccess.description: The Fiend is not further affected by planar dissonance this Long Rest.

recoveryMethods: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to the creature's nature ends the cumulative effect.

planarDissonance.description: Fiends who visit Mount Celestia (an Upper Plane) experience significant discomfort if their visits last more than a few hours. After finishing a Long Rest on the plane, a Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save and ends when the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature.

domainsOrRegions.name: Excelsior
domainsOrRegions.description: A gate-town in the Outlands built around a portal leading to Mount Celestia. Excelsior shares many of the characteristics of Mount Celestia.

adventureThemes: Proving oneself worthy of celestial blessings
Defending against incursions of evil from the Lower Planes
Retrieving holy items or remains from other planes

adventureSituations.situation: A foolhardy knight carried a holy weapon on a doomed mission into the Nine Hells, and the powers of Mount Celestia want the weapon and the knight's remains retrieved.

crossReferences.description: Environmental Effects of Mount Celestia referenced in Chapter 3 under Environmental Effects.
Planar Dissonance rules for Fiends visiting Upper Planes described in Chapter 6: Cosmology under Alignment and the Outer Planes.

globalPlanarConnections.name: Infinite Staircase
globalPlanarConnections.description: An extradimensional staircase that connects the planes. An entrance usually appears as a nondescript door. Beyond the portal lies a small landing with a stairway leading up and down. The Infinite Staircase changes appearance as it climbs and descends.
hazards: Doors guarded by devas, sphinxes, yugoloths, and other powerful monsters

globalPlanarConnections.name: River Oceanus
globalPlanarConnections.description: The water of the Oceanus is sweet and fragrant, originating in the lowest layer of Elysium, Thalasia, flowing through Elysium's layers, passing through the top layer of the Beastlands, streaming across the top layer of Arborea, and draining away in Arborea's second layer.

globalPlanarConnections.name: River Styx
globalPlanarConnections.description: The River Styx bubbles with grease, foul flotsam, and putrid remains. It churns through the top layers of Acheron, the Nine Hells, Gehenna, Hades, Carceri, the Abyss, and Pandemonium. Tributaries snake through lower layers.
hazards: Memory loss from contact with waters

globalPlanarConnections.name: Yggdrasil, the World Tree
globalPlanarConnections.description: A cosmic ash tree that spans the Outer Planes and links them to many worlds of the Material Plane. Its roots stretch into the Lower Planes, most of its trunk rises through Ysgard, and its branches stretch through the Upper Planes and across the Astral to the Material Plane.
hazards: Ever-changing paths as the tree continues eternal growth

planarTravelMethods.name: Planar Portals
planarTravelMethods.description: A portal is a stationary, interplanar connection that links a specific location on one plane to a specific location on another. Some function like doorways, others are locations existing on multiple planes at once or flickering between planes.
requirements: Meeting the portal's requirements (command, key item, random timing, situation, or time-based)
risks: Guardians charged with ensuring certain creatures don't pass through
Portals not open all the time
destinations: Any plane connected by the specific portal

planarTravelMethods.name: Planar Travel Spells
planarTravelMethods.description: A number of spells allow direct or indirect access to different planes of existence.
requirements: Ability to cast the appropriate spell
risks: Varying degrees of precision in destination
destinations: Any plane depending on spell used

planarAdventureSituations.situation: When magic fails to revive a dead person, the only solution is to venture to the Outer Planes to find the person's spirit and either release it from some prison or convince the person to return to life.

People who venture into the woods keep accidentally wandering into the Feywild or the Shadowfell. They might never return, return with no sense of how much time has passed, or return dramatically changed.
A long-dead oracle is the only one who knows how a terrible prophecy might be averted, but the cataclysmic fulfillment of the prophecy has already begun.
A god has stopped answering prayers and won't respond to any Commune spell.
A devil has tricked an angel into meddling in the Blood War, and the angel seeks mortal aid.
An ancestor of one of the characters must be convinced to bless the character before the full power of the character's bloodline can be unleashed.
A foolhardy knight carried a holy weapon on a doomed mission into the Nine Hells, and the powers of Mount Celestia want the weapon and the knight's remains retrieved.
A titan is imprisoned on an Outer Plane. The characters might be trying to stop those who seek to release it, or they might want to release it to help defend the world from a greater threat.

To prove themselves worthy of an even greater quest, the characters are sent to slay a horrible monster, win the favor of a powerful planar being, negotiate peace between two warring planar factions, or retrieve a long-lost item on another plane.
An item of legend is being sold at auction in Sigil, the City of Brass, or some other planar metropolis.

globalPlanarDissonance.description: Celestials who visit the Lower Planes and Fiends who visit the Upper Planes experience significant discomfort if their visits last more than a few hours. After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to its nature, a Celestial or Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save and ends when the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature.

savingThrow.triggerDescription: After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to the creature's nature.

onFailure.description: Whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save.
onFailure.cumulativeDescription: Each failed save adds another 1d4 penalty subtracted from all D20 Tests. The cumulative penalty stacks with previous failed saves.

onSuccess.description: The creature is not further affected by planar dissonance this Long Rest.

recoveryMethods: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to the creature's nature ends all cumulative planar dissonance effects.

savingThrowProbabilities.formula: P(fail | modifier m) = max(0.05, min(0.95, (DC - 1 - m) / 20))
